{{see also|Potentiality and actuality}} [[File:Aristotle's Four Causes of a Table.svg|thumb|upright=2|[[Aristotle]]'s Four Causes illustrated for a table: material (wood), formal (design), efficient (carpentry), final (dining).]] The "'''four causes'''" are elements of an influential principle in [[Aristotelianism|Aristotelian thought]] whereby explanations of change or movement are classified into four fundamental types of answer to the question "why?". [[Aristotle]] wrote that "we do not have knowledge of a thing until we have grasped its why, that is to say, its cause."<ref>Aristotle, ''Physics'' 194 b17–20; see also: {{nowrap|''Posterior Analytics'' 71 b9–11; 94 a20.}}</ref><ref name="SEP Four Causes"> "[F]or a full range of cases, an explanation which fails to invoke all four causes is no explanation at all."—[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/aristotle-causality/#FouCau "Four Causes"]. Falcon, Andrea. [http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/aristotle-causality/ Aristotle on Causality]. ''Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy'' 2008.</ref> While there are cases where identifying a "cause" is difficult, or in which "causes" might merge, Aristotle held that his four "causes" provided an analytical scheme of general applicability.<ref>Lindberg, David. ''The Beginnings of Western Science'' (1992). p. 53</ref>
'''''Aitia''''', from [[Greek language|Greek]] {{lang|grc|αἰτία}}, was the word that Aristotle used to refer to the causal explanation that has traditionally been translated as "cause", but this specialized, technical, philosophical usage of the word "cause" does not correspond exactly to its most usual applications in everyday English language.{{sfn|Leroi|2015|pages=91–92}} The translation of Aristotle's {{lang|grc|αἰτία}} that is nearest to current ordinary language could be "question" or "causal explanation",<ref name="Hankison1998" /><ref name="SEP Four Causes"/>{{sfn|Leroi|2015|pages=91–92}} although any such terms may mask the fact that Aristotelians consider the four causes to be more fundamental in nature than mere explanations. In this article, the peculiar philosophical usage of the word "cause" will be employed, for tradition's sake, but the reader should not be misled by confusing this technical usage with current ordinary language.
Aristotle held that there were four kinds of answers to "why" questions (in ''[[Physics (Aristotle)|Physics]]'' II, 3, and ''[[Metaphysics (Aristotle)|Metaphysics]]'' V, 2):<ref name="SEP Four Causes"/><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0052%3Abook%3D5%3Asection%3D1013a |title=Metaphysics |chapter=Book 5, section 1013a |others=Translated by Hugh Tredennick |author=Aristotle}} Aristotle in 23 Volumes, Vols. 17, 18, Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann Ltd. 1933, 1989; (hosted at perseus.tufts.edu.) Aristotle also discusses the four "causes" in his Physics, Book B, chapter 3.</ref><ref name="Hankison1998">{{Citation | last=Hankinson | first=R. J. | date=1998 | title=Cause and Explanation in Ancient Greek Thought | publisher=OUP Premium | place=[Oxford] | page=159 | isbn=9780198237457 | format=e-book | doi=10.1093/0199246564.001.0001 | quote=Aristotle famously distinguishes four 'causes' (or causal factors in explanation), the matter, the form, the end, and the agent.}}</ref> * '''Matter''': a change or movement's '''material cause''', is the aspect of the change or movement which is determined by the material that composes the moving or changing things. For a table, that might be wood; for a statue, that might be bronze or marble. * '''Form''': a change or movement's '''formal cause''', is a change or movement caused by the arrangement, shape or appearance of the thing changing or moving. Aristotle says for example that the ratio 2:1, and number in general, is the cause of the [[octave]]. * '''Agent''': a change or movement's '''efficient''' or '''moving cause''', consists of things apart from the thing being changed or moved, which interact so as to be an agency of the change or movement. For example, the efficient cause of a table is a carpenter, or a person working as one, and according to Aristotle the efficient cause of a boy is a father. * '''End''' or '''purpose''': a change or movement's '''final cause''', is that for the sake of which a thing is what it is. For a seed, it might be an adult plant. For a sailboat, it might be sailing. For a ball at the top of a ramp, it might be coming to rest at the bottom. The four "causes" are not mutually exclusive. For Aristotle, several answers to the question "why" have to be given to explain a phenomenon and especially the actual configuration of an object.<ref>According to Reece (2018): "Aristotle thinks that human action is a species of animal self-movement, and animal self-movement is a species of natural change. Natural changes, although they are not substances and do not have causes in precisely the same way that substances do, are to be explained in terms of the four causes, or as many of them as a given natural change has: The material cause is that out of which something comes to be, or what undergoes change from one state to another; the formal cause, what differentiates something from other things, and serves as a paradigm for its coming to be that thing; the efficient cause, the starting-point of change; the final cause, that for the sake of which something comes about."</ref> For example, if asking why a table is such and such, a complete explanation, taking into account the four causes, would sound like this: This table is solid and brown because it is made of wood (matter), it does not collapse because it has four legs of equal length (form), it is as such because a carpenter made it starting from a tree (agent), it has these dimensions because it is to be used by men and women (end).
==Meaning of "cause"==
In his philosophical writings, Aristotle used the [[Greek (language)|Greek]] word [[wikt:αἴτιος|αἴτιον]], ''aition'', a neuter singular form of an adjective. The Greek word had meant, perhaps originally in a [[Ancient Greek law | "legal"]] context, what or who is "[[Personal responsibility|responsible]]", mostly but not always in a bad sense of "guilt" or "blame"; alternatively it could mean "to the credit of" someone or something. The appropriation of this word by Aristotle and other philosophers reflects how the Greek experience of legal practice influenced the concern in Greek thought to determine ''what'' is responsible.<ref>{{Citation | last=Lloyd | first=G. E. R. | author-link=G. E. R. Lloyd | date=1996 | title=Adversaries and authorities: Investigations into ancient Greek and Chinese science | chapter=Causes and correlations | publisher=Cambridge University Press | place=Cambridge | pages=100, 106–107 | isbn=0-521-55695-3 }}</ref> The word developed other meanings, including its use in philosophy in a more abstract sense.<ref>[http://www.hs-augsburg.de/~harsch/graeca/Chronologia/S_ante04/Aristoteles/ari_a221.html original text in ''Posterior Analytics'' 90a8, 94a20], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0051%3Abook%3D5%3Asection%3D1013a original text in ''Met.'' 1013a on Perseus]</ref><ref>{{ Citation | last=Liddell | first=Henry G. | author-link=Henry Liddell | last2=Scott | first2=Robert | author2-link=Robert Scott (philologist) | last3=Jones | first3=Henry Stuart | author3-link=Henry Stuart Jones | date= | origyear=1843 | title=The Online Liddell-Scott-Jones Greek-English Lexicon | publisher=Thesaurus Linguae Graecae | url=http://stephanus.tlg.uci.edu/lsj/#eid=2906&context=lsj&action=from-search }}</ref> About a century before Aristotle, the anonymous author of the [[Hippocratic Corpus|Hippocratic]] text ''[[On Ancient Medicine]]'' had described the essential characteristics of a cause: "We must, therefore, consider the causes of each [medical] condition to be those things which are such that, when they are present, the condition necessarily occurs, but when they change to another combination, it ceases."<ref>{{Citation | last=Lloyd | first=G. E. R. | authorlink=G. E. R. Lloyd | date=1979 | title=Magic, Reason and Experience | publisher=Cambridge University Press | place=Cambridge | isbn=0-521-29641-2 | page=54 }}</ref> In the present context, Aristotle used the four causes to provide different answers to the question, "because of what?" The four answers to this question illuminate different aspects of how a thing comes into being or of how an event takes place.<ref>{{ Citation | last=Lloyd | first=G. E. R. | author-link=G. E. R. Lloyd | date=1996 | title=Adversaries and authorities: Investigations into ancient Greek and Chinese science | chapter=Causes and correlations | publisher=Cambridge University Press | place=Cambridge | pages=96–98 | isbn=0-521-55695-3 }}</ref>
=== {{anchor|Material cause}} Matter ===
Aristotle considers the '''material "cause"''' (''hyle'')<ref name=preus>{{cite dictionary |author=Preus, Anthony |year=2015 |title=Material cause |work=Historical Dictionary of Ancient Greek Philosophy |edition=2nd |publisher=Rowman and Littlefield |url=https://books.google.com.br/books?id=wjW_BgAAQBAJ |isbn=978-0810854871}}</ref> of an object as equivalent to the nature of the raw material out of which the object is composed. (The word "nature" for Aristotle applies to both its potential in the raw material and its ultimate finished form. In a sense this form already existed in the material: see [[potentiality and actuality]].)
Whereas modern physics looks to simple bodies, Aristotle's physics instead treated living things as exemplary. However, he felt that simple natural bodies such as earth, fire, air, and water also showed signs of having their own innate sources of motion, change, and rest. Fire, for example, carries things upwards, unless stopped from doing so. Things like beds and cloaks, formed by human artifice, have no innate tendency to become beds or cloaks.<ref>''[[Physics (Aristotle)|Physics]]'' 192b</ref>
In Aristotelian terminology, material is not the same as [[Substance theory|substance]]. Matter has parallels with substance in so far as primary matter serves as the substratum for simple bodies which are not substance: sand and rock (mostly earth), rivers and seas (mostly water), atmosphere and wind (mostly air and then mostly fire below the moon). Only individuals are said to be substance (subjects) in the primary sense. Secondary substance, in a different sense, also applies to man-made artifacts.
=== {{anchor|Formal cause}} Form === {{see|Platonic realism}}
Aristotle considers the '''formal "cause"''' (''eidos'')<ref name=preus/> as describing the pattern or form which when present makes matter into a particular type of thing, which we recognize as being of that particular type.
By Aristotle's own account, this is a difficult and controversial [[concept]].{{citation needed|date= September 2016}} It links with [[theory of forms|theories of forms]] such as those of Aristotle's teacher, [[Plato]], but in Aristotle's own account (see his ''[[Metaphysics (Aristotle)|Metaphysics]]''), he takes into account many previous writers who had expressed opinions about forms and ideas, but he shows how his own views differ from them.<ref>{{Citation | last=Lloyd | first=G. E. R. | author-link=G. E. R. Lloyd | date=1968 | title=Aristotle: The Growth and Structure of His Thought | chapter=The critic of Plato | publisher=Cambridge University Press | place=Cambridge | pages=43–47 | isbn=0-521-09456-9 }}</ref>
=== {{anchor|Efficient cause}} Agent ===
Aristotle defines the '''agent''' or '''efficient "cause"''' (''kinoun'')<ref name=preus/> of an object as that which causes change and motion to start or stop (such as a painter painting a house) (see Aristotle, Physics II 3, 194b29). In many cases, this is simply the thing that brings something about. For example, in the case of a statue, it is the person chiseling away which transforms a block of marble into a statue. Only this one of the four causes is like what an ordinary English-speaker would regard as a cause.<ref>{{ Citation | last=Lloyd | first=G. E. R. | author-link=G. E. R. Lloyd | date=1996 | title=Adversaries and authorities: Investigations into ancient Greek and Chinese science | chapter=Causes and correlations | publisher=Cambridge University Press | place=Cambridge | page=96 | isbn=0-521-55695-3 | quote=It is clear that of these four, only the efficient cause looks like a ''cause'' in any ordinary English sense.}}</ref>
=== {{anchor|Final cause}} End === {{Main article|Teleology}}
Aristotle defines the '''end''', '''purpose''', or '''final "cause"''' (''telos'')<ref name=preus/> as that for the sake of which a thing is done.<ref>{{Citation | author=Aristotle | author-link=Aristotle | title=Physics | at=II.3. 194 <sup>b 32</sup>}}</ref> Like the form, this is a controversial type of explanation in science; some have argued for its survival in [[evolutionary biology]],<ref name="Lennox 1993">{{ Citation | last=Lennox | first=James G. | author-link=James G. Lennox | date=1993 | title=Darwin ''was'' a teleologist | journal=Biology and Philosophy | volume=8 | issue=4 | pages=409–421 | doi=10.1007/BF00857687 }}</ref> while [[Ernst Mayr]] denied that it continued to play a role.<ref>{{ Citation | last=Mayr | first=Ernst | author-link=Ernst Mayr | date=10 November 1961 | title=Cause and Effect in Biology | volume=134 | issue=3489 | pages=1501–1506 | quote= The development or behavior of an individual is purposive, natural selection is definitely not…. Darwin 'has swept out such finalistic teleology by the front door.' }}</ref> It is commonly claimed{{by whom?|date=March 2018}} that Aristotle's conception of nature is teleological in the sense that [[Nature (philosophy)|Nature]] has goals apart from those that humans have. On the other hand, as discussed further below, it has also been claimed that Aristotle thought that a ''telos'' can be present without any form of deliberation, consciousness or intelligence. An example of a relevant passage occurs in ''Physics'' II.8, where he writes:
{{quote|This is most obvious in the animals other than man: they make things neither by art nor after inquiry or deliberation. That is why people wonder whether it is by intelligence or by some other faculty that these creatures work, – spiders, ants, and the like... It is absurd to suppose that purpose is not present because we do not observe the agent deliberating. Art does not deliberate. If the ship-building art were in the wood, it would produce the same results by nature. If, therefore, purpose is present in art, it is present also in nature.<ref>''The Complete Works of Aristotle'' Vol. I. The Revised Oxford Translation, ed. Jonathan Barnes).</ref>}}
For example, according to Aristotle, a seed has the eventual adult plant as its end (i.e., as its ''telos'') if and only if the seed would become the adult plant under normal circumstances.<ref>Aristotle gives this example in ''Parts of Animals'' I.1.</ref> In ''Physics'' II.9, Aristotle hazards a few arguments that a determination of the end (cause) of a phenomenon is more important than the others. He argues that the end is that which brings it about, so for example "if one defines the operation of sawing as being a certain kind of dividing, then this cannot come about unless the saw has teeth of a certain kind; and these cannot be unless it is of iron."<ref>Aristotle, ''Physics'' II.9. 200b4–7.</ref> According to Aristotle, once a final "cause" is in place, the material, efficient and formal "causes" follow by necessity. However, he recommends that the student of nature determine the other "causes" as well,<ref>Aristotle, ''Physics'' II.9.</ref> and notes that not all phenomena have an end, e.g., chance events.<ref>''Physics'' II.5 where chance is opposed to nature, which he has already said acts for ends.</ref>
Aristotle saw that [[Aristotle's biology|his biological investigations]] provided insights into the causes of things, especially into the final cause. {{quote|We should approach the investigation of every kind of animal without being ashamed, since in each one of them there is something natural and something beautiful. The absence of chance and the serving of ends are found in the works of nature especially. And the end, for the sake of which a thing has been constructed or has come to be, belongs to what is beautiful. |source=Aristotle, ''On the Parts of Animals'' 645<sup>a 21-26</sup>, Book I, Part 5.<ref>Lloyd, G. E. R. (1970). ''Early Greek Science: Thales to Aristotle'', New York: W. W. Norton, p. 105. ISBN 978-0-393-00583-7 </ref>}}
[[George Holmes Howison]], in ''The Limits of Evolution'' (1901), highlights "final causation" in presenting his theory of metaphysics, which he terms "personal idealism", and to which he invites not only man, but all (ideal) life; at p. 39:
{{quote|Here, in seeing that Final Cause – causation at the call of self-posited aim or end – is the only full and genuine cause, we further see that Nature, the cosmic aggregate of phenomena and the cosmic bond of their law which in the mood of vague and inaccurate abstraction we call Force, is after all only an effect... Thus teleology, or the Reign of Final Cause, the reign of ideality, is not only an element in the notion of Evolution, but is the very vital cord in the notion. The conception of evolution is founded at last and essentially in the conception of Progress: but this conception has no meaning at all except in the light of a goal; there can be no goal unless there is a Beyond for everything actual; and there is no such Beyond except through a spontaneous ideal. The presupposition of Nature, as a system undergoing evolution, is therefore the causal activity of our Pure Ideals. These are our three organic and organizing conceptions called the True, the Beautiful, and the Good.}}
However, [[Edward Feser]] argues, in line with the Aristotelian and [[Thomism|Thomistic]] tradition, that finality has been greatly misunderstood. Indeed, without finality, efficient causality becomes inexplicable. Finality thus understood is not purpose but that end towards which a thing is ordered.<ref>Compare: {{cite book | last1=Feser | first1=Edward | orig-year=2009 | title=Aquinas: A Beginner's Guide | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J2qhHE-6Mn4C | series=Beginner's Guides | edition=Reprint | location=Oxford | publisher=Oneworld Publications | publication-date=2011 | page=| isbn=9781780740065 | access-date=2018-03-12 | quote=[...] three principles are central to Aquinas's general metaphysics [...] the principle of finality is in a sense the most fundamental of them, given that the final cause is 'the cause of causes': for, again in Aquinas's' view an efficient cause can bring an effect in to being only if it is 'directed towards' that effect; and it is ultimately in that sense that the effect is 'contained in' the efficient cause.}}</ref> When a match is rubbed against the side of a matchbox, the effect is not the appearance of an elephant or the sounding of a drum, but fire.<ref> Compare: {{cite book | last1=Feser | first1=Edward | orig-year=2009 | title=Aquinas: A Beginner's Guide | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J2qhHE-6Mn4C | series=Beginner's Guides | edition=Reprint | location=Oxford | publisher=Oneworld Publications | publication-date=2011 | page=| isbn=9781780740065 | access-date=2018-03-12 | quote=A match, for example, reliably generates flame and heat when struck, and never (say) frost and cold, or the smell of lilacs, or thunder.}}</ref> The effect is not arbitrary because the match is ordered towards the end of fire<ref>Compare:The match is 'directed towards' the production of fire and heat [...]</ref> which is realized through efficient causes.
In their theoretical study of organism, more specifically propagating organisation of process, Kauffman ''et al.'' remark (p30): {{quote|Our language is teleological. We believe that autonomous agents constitute the minimal physical system to which teleological language rightly applies.<ref> Kauffman, S., Logan, R. K., Este, R., Goebel, R., Hobill, D., & Shmulevich, I. (2008). Propagating organization: An enquiry. Biology & Philosophy, 23(1), 27-45.</ref>}}
==In modern science== {{See also|Teleology#Teleology and science}}
[[Francis Bacon]] wrote in his ''[[Advancement of Learning]]'' (1605) that natural science "doth make inquiry, and take consideration of the same natures : but how? Only as to the material and efficient causes of them, and not as to the forms." According to the demands of Bacon, apart from the "[[Physical law|laws of nature]]" themselves, the causes relevant to natural [[science]] are only [[efficient cause]]s and [[material cause]]s in terms of Aristotle's classification, or to use the formulation which became famous later, all nature visible to human science is matter and motion. Using the terminology of Aristotle, he divided knowledge into physics and metaphysics in ''[[The New Organon]]''. <blockquote>From the two kinds of axioms which have been spoken of arises a just division of philosophy and the sciences, taking the received terms (which come nearest to express the thing) in a sense agreeable to my own views. Thus, let the investigation of forms, which are (in the eye of reason at least, and in their essential law) eternal and immutable, constitute [[Metaphysics]]; and let the investigation of the efficient cause, and of matter, and of the latent process, and the latent configuration (all of which have reference to the common and ordinary course of nature, not to her eternal and fundamental laws) constitute [[Physics]]. And to these let there be subordinate two practical divisions: to Physics, Mechanics; to Metaphysics, what (in a purer sense of the word) I call Magic, on account of the broadness of the ways it moves in, and its greater command over nature. Francis Bacon ''The New Organon'', Book II, Aphorism 9, 1620</blockquote>
Bacon's position became the standard one for modern science.
===Biology=== {{main article|Teleology in biology}}
Explanations in terms of final causes remain common [[Teleology in biology|in evolutionary biology]].<ref name="Lennox 1993"/><ref name="Ayala 1998">[[Francisco J. Ayala|Ayala, Francisco]] (1998). "Teleological explanations in evolutionary biology." ''Nature's purposes: Analyses of Function and Design in Biology''. The MIT Press.</ref> [[Francisco J. Ayala]] has claimed that teleology is indispensable to biology since the concept of [[adaptation]] is inherently teleological.<ref name="Ayala 1998" /> In an appreciation of [[Charles Darwin]] published in ''Nature'' in 1874, [[Asa Gray]] noted "Darwin's great service to Natural Science" lies in bringing back Teleology "so that, instead of Morphology ''versus'' Teleology, we shall have Morphology wedded to Teleology". Darwin quickly responded, "What you say about Teleology pleases me especially and I do not think anyone else has ever noticed the point."<ref name="Lennox 1993"/> [[Francis Darwin]] and [[T. H. Huxley]] reiterate this sentiment. The latter wrote that "..the most remarkable service to the philosophy of Biology rendered by Mr. Darwin is the reconciliation of Teleology and Morphology, and the explanation of the facts of both, which his view offers."<ref name="Lennox 1993"/> [[James G. Lennox]] states that Darwin uses the term 'Final Cause' consistently in his ''Species Notebook'', ''Origin of Species'' and after.<ref name="Lennox 1993"/>
Contrary to the position described by [[Francisco J. Ayala]], [[Ernst Mayr]] states that "adaptedness... is ''[[Empirical evidence|a posteriori]]'' result rather than an a priori goal-seeking."<ref>[[Ernst Mayr|Mayr, Ernst W.]] (1992). "The idea of teleology" ''Journal of the History of Ideas'', 53, 117–135.</ref> Various commentators view the teleological phrases used in modern evolutionary biology as a type of shorthand. For example, S. H. P. Madrell writes that "the proper but cumbersome way of describing change by evolutionary adaptation [may be] substituted by shorter overtly teleological statements" for the sake of saving space, but that this "should not be taken to imply that evolution proceeds by anything other than from mutations arising by chance, with those that impart an advantage being retained by natural selection."<ref>Madrell SHP (1998) "Why are there no insects in the open sea?" ''The Journal of Experimental Biology'' '''201''':2461–2464.</ref> However, Lennox states that in evolution as conceived by Darwin, it is true both that evolution is the result of mutations arising by chance and that evolution is teleological in nature.<ref name="Lennox 1993" />
Statements that a species does something "in order to" achieve survival are teleological. The validity or invalidity of such statements depends on the species and the intention of the writer as to the meaning of the phrase "in order to". Sometimes it is possible or useful to rewrite such sentences so as to avoid teleology.<ref name=Reiss>{{cite book |author=Reiss, John O. |date=2009 |title=Not by Design: Retiring Darwin's Watchmaker |publisher=University of California Press |page= }}</ref> Some biology courses have incorporated exercises requiring students to rephrase such sentences so that they do not read teleologically. Nevertheless, biologists still frequently write in a way which can be read as implying teleology even if that is not the intention.
==Heidegger on technology==
In ''[[The Question Concerning Technology]]'', [[Martin Heidegger]] describes the four causes as follows:
#''causa materialis'' is the material or matter # ''causa formalis'' is the form or shape the material or matter enters # ''causa finalis'' is the end # ''causa efficiens'' is the effect that brings about the finished result.{{sfn|Heidegger|1977|pp=289-290}}
Heidegger explains it thus:
{{quote|Whoever builds a house or a ship or forges a sacrificial chalice reveals what is to be brought forth, according to the terms of the four modes of occasioning.{{sfn|Heidegger|1977|p=295}}}}
The educationist David Waddington comments that although the efficient cause, which he identifies as "the craftsman", might be thought the most significant of the four, in his view each of Heidegger's four causes is "equally co-responsible" for producing a craft item, in Heidegger's terms "bringing forth" the thing into existence. Waddington cites Lovitt's description of this bringing forth as "a unified process".<ref name="Waddington2005">{{cite journal |author=Waddington, David |title=A Field Guide to Heidegger Understanding {{!}} ''The Question Concerning Technology'' |journal=Educational Philosophy and Theory |date=2005 |volume=37 |issue=4 |page=568 |url=https://www.academia.edu/540032/A_Field_Guide_to_Heidegger_Understanding_The_Question_concerning_Technology}}</ref><ref name=Lovitt1972>{{cite journal |author=Lovitt, W. |date=1972 |title=A Gesprach with Heidegger on Technology, Man and World |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=44–62}}</ref>
==Tinbergen's four questions== {{main|Tinbergen's four questions}}
[[Tinbergen's four questions]], named after the [[ethologist]] [[Nikolaas Tinbergen]] and based on Aristotle's four causes, are complementary categories of explanations for [[animal behaviour]]. They are also commonly referred to as levels of analysis. The four questions are on [[function (biology)|function]], what an [[adaptation]] does that is [[natural selection|selected for]] in [[evolution]]; [[phylogeny]], the evolutionary history of an [[organism]], revealing its relationships to other species; [[mechanism (biology)|mechanism]], namely the proximate cause of a behaviour, such as the role of [[testosterone]] in [[aggression]]; and [[ontogeny]], the [[developmental biology|development]] of an organism from egg to embryo to adult.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=MacDougall-Shackleton |first=Scott A. |date=2011-07-27 |title=The levels of analysis revisited |journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences |volume=366 |issue=1574 |pages=2076–2085 |doi=10.1098/rstb.2010.0363 |pmc=3130367 |pmid=21690126}}</ref><ref name=h&h>Hladký, V. & Havlíček, J. (2013). ''[http://ishe.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/HEB_2013_28_4_3-11.pdf Was Tinbergen an Aristotelian? Comparison of Tinbergen's Four Whys and Aristotle's Four Causes]''. ''Human Ethology Bulletin'', 28(4), 3-11</ref>
==See also== {{col div|colwidth=30em}} * [[Anthropic principle]] * [[Biosemiotics]] * [[Causality]] * [[Convergent evolution]] * [[Four discourses]], by [[Jacques Lacan]] * [[Proximate and ultimate causation]] * [[Socrates]] * [[Teleology]] * [[The purpose of a system is what it does]], [[Anthony Stafford Beer]]'s POSIWID principle {{colend}}

[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/aristotle-causality/#FouCau Aristotle on Causality] (link to section labeled "Four Causes"). ''Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy'' 2008. * {{cite book |authorlink=Martin Heidegger |last=Heidegger |first=Martin |editor=Krell, D. F. |title=The Question Concerning Technology |work=Basic Writings |publisher=Harper & Row |year=1977 |ref=harv}} * Hennig, Boris. "The Four Causes." Journal of Philosophy 106(3), 2009, 137–60. * {{cite book |authorlink=Armand Marie Leroi |last=Leroi |first=Armand Marie |title=The Lagoon: How Aristotle Invented Science |titlelink=Aristotle's Lagoon |publisher=Bloomsbury |date=2015 |isbn=978-1408836224 |ref=harv}} * Moravcsik, J.M. "Aitia as generative factor in Aristotle's philosophy." Dialogue, 14 : pp 622–638, 1975. * {{cite journal |author=Reece, Bryan C. |title=Aristotle's Four Causes of Action |journal=Australasian Journal of Philosophy |date=2018 |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi=10.1080/00048402.2018.1482932}} * English translation of [http://www.humanistmovement.org/downloads/Pia_fugera_study_Estudio_sobre_Fidias-PF-eng-final.pdf Study on Phideas], by Pía Figueroa written with theme of Final Cause as per Aristotle. {{div col end}}

Sproul] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=76mfL03rjdUC&lpg=PT94&lr=&as_brr=3&pg=PT91#v=onepage&q=&f=false Aristotle on definition. By Marguerite Deslauriers, page 81] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=L0w6kvdKJ8QC&lpg=PA201&dq=%22four%20causes%22&lr=&as_brr=3&pg=PA201#v=onepage&q=%22four%20causes%22&f=false Philosophy in the ancient world: an introduction. By James A. Arieti. p. 201.] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=IXMsL2XG-3cC&lpg=PA178&pg=PA157#v=onepage&q=&f=false Doctrine of Being in the Aristotelian Metaphysics. In mathematics, '''Hopf conjecture''' may refer to one of several conjectural statements from [[differential geometry]] and [[topology]] attributed to either [[Eberhard Hopf]] or [[Heinz Hopf]].
== Positively curved Riemannian manifolds ==
: ''A compact, even-dimensional [[Riemannian manifold]] with positive [[sectional curvature]] has positive [[Euler characteristic]]''
For [[differential geometry of surfaces|surfaces]], this follows from the [[Gauss–Bonnet theorem]]. For [[4-manifold|four-dimensional manifolds]], this follows from the finiteness of the [[fundamental group]] and [[Poincaré duality]]. The conjecture has been proved for manifolds of dimension 4''k''+2 or 4''k''+4 admitting an isometric [[torus action]] of a ''k''-dimensional torus and for manifolds ''M'' admitting an isometric action of a compact [[Lie group]] ''G'' with principal isotropy subgroup ''H'' and cohomogeneity ''k'' such that
: <math> k-(\operatorname{rank} G-\operatorname{rank} H)\leq 5. </math>
In a related conjecture, "positive" is replaced with "nonnegative".
== Riemannian symmetric spaces == : ''A compact [[symmetric space]] of rank greater than one cannot carry a Riemannian metric of positive sectional curvature.''
In particular, the four-dimensional manifold ''S''<sup>2</sup>×''S''<sup>2</sup> should admit no [[Riemannian metric]] with positive sectional curvature.
== Aspherical manifolds == : ''Suppose M<sup>2k</sup> is a closed, [[aspherical manifold]] of even dimension. Then its Euler characteristic satisfies the inequality''
:: <math> (-1)^k\chi(M^{2k})\geq 0. </math>
This topological version of Hopf conjecture for [[Riemannian manifold]]s is due to [[William Thurston]]. [[Ruth Charney]] and [[Michael Davis (mathematician)|Michael Davis]] conjectured that the same inequality holds for a nonpositively curved piecewise Euclidean (PE) manifold.
== Metrics with no conjugate points==
: ''A Riemannian metric without conjugate points on n-dimensional torus is flat.''
This theorem was proved by Dmitri Burago and Sergei Ivanov.<ref>Dmitri Burago and Sergei Ivanov, ''Riemannian tori without conjugate points are flat'', [[Geometric and Functional Analysis]] '''4''' (1994), no. 3, 259-269, {{doi| 10.1007/BF01896241}}, {{MR|1274115}}.</ref>
== References == <references/> * Thomas Püttmann and Catherine Searle, [http://www.ams.org/proc/2002-130-01/S0002-9939-01-06039-7/S0002-9939-01-06039-7.pdf ''The Hopf conjecture for manifolds with low cohomogeneity or high symmetry rank''], [[Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society]] '''130''' (2001), no. 1, 163–166.

{{Infobox holiday|holiday_name=International Day of the Girl Child|type=international|nickname=International Day of the Girl, Day of Girls|date=11 October|frequency=annual|duration=1 day|significance=[[Raising awareness]] of issues facing girls internationally, such as education, nutrition, child marriage, legal and medical rights|firsttime=11 October 2012}} {{Feminism sidebar}}
'''International Day of the Girl Child''' is an international observance day declared by the United Nations; it is also called the '''Day of Girls''' and the '''International Day of the Girl'''. [[October 11]], 2012, was the first Day of the Girl Child. The observation supports more opportunity for girls and increases awareness of [[gender inequality]] faced by girls worldwide based upon their gender. This inequality includes areas such as [[right to education|access to education]], nutrition, legal rights, medical care, and protection from discrimination, [[violence against women]] and [[forced marriage|forced]] [[child marriage]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/10/united-nations-malala-girls-education.html|title=As Malala Recovers, U.N. Marks International Day of the Girl Child|last=|first=|date=11 October 2012|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref> The celebration of the day also "reflects the successful [[emergence]] of girls and young women as a distinct cohort in development policy, programming, campaigning and research."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uepcBgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA903&dq=%22international%20day%20of%20the%20girl%22&pg=PA895#v=onepage&q=%22international%20day%20of%20the%20girl%22&f=false|title=The Oxford Handbook of Transnational Feminist Movements|last=Hendricks|first=Sarah|last2=Bachan|first2=Keshet|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2015|isbn=9780199943494|editor-last=Baksh|editor-first=Rawwida|location=|pages=895|chapter=Because I Am a Girl: The Emergence of Girls in Development|editor-last2=Harcourt|editor-first2=Wendy|via=}}</ref>
==Background== International Day of the Girl increases awareness of issues faced by girls around the world. Many{{how many|date=June 2017}} global development plans{{which|date=June 2017}} do not include or consider girls, and their issues become "invisible."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/10/06/242172.html|title=World Gears for First Ever 'International Day of the Girl Child'|last=|first=|date=6 October 2012|work=Al Arabiya|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref> More than 62 million girls around the world have no access to education.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/first-lady-michelle-obama-champions-education-day-girl-n664066|title=Michelle Obama Calls for 'Soldiers' in Fight for Girls Education|last=Bailey|first=Chelsea|date=11 October 2016|work=NBC News|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref> Worldwide and collectively, girls ages 5 to 14 spend more than 160 million hours more on [[Housekeeping|household chores]] than boys of the same age do.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://motto.time.com/4526281/international-day-girl-2016/|title=What to Know About the UN’s International Day of the Girl|last=Haynes|first=Suyin|date=11 October 2016|work=Motto|publisher=TIME|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref> Globally, one in four girls are married before age 18.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/oct/11/how-are-you-marking-international-day-of-the-girl-share-your-stories-guardianwitness|title=How Are You Marking International Day of the Girl? Share Your Stories|last=Ford|first=Liz|date=11 October 2016|work=The Guardian|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref> On October 11, 2016, [[Emma Watson]], who is also the United Nations Women's Goodwill Ambassador, urged countries and families worldwide to end [[child marriage]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/2016/1011/Emma-Watson-s-powerful-words-on-International-Day-of-the-Girl|title=Emma Watson's Powerful Words on International Day of the Girl|last=Beck|first=Christina|date=11 October 2016|work=The Christian Science Monitor|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref> Many{{how many|date=June 2017}} girls around the world are [[social vulnerability|vulnerable]] to acts of [[sexual violence]] and the [[Suspect|perpetrators]] often{{how often|date=June 2017}} go unpunished.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2012/10/20121010614437332.html|title=A Much Needed International Day of the Girl|last=Picq|first=Manuela|date=11 October 2012|work=Al Jazeera|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref>
The Day of Girls helps raise awareness not only of the issues that girls face, but also what is likely to happen when those problems are solved. For example, educating girls helps reduce the rate of child marriage, disease and helps strengthen the [[economy]] by helping girls have access to higher paying jobs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://schoolsofthought.blogs.cnn.com/2012/10/11/education-a-focus-on-international-day-of-the-girl-child/|title=Education a Focus on International Day of the Girl Child|last=Krache|first=Donna|date=11 October 2012|work=CNN|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/camille-crittenden/science-math-programs-matter_b_1944249.html|title=International Day of the Girl: Why Science & Math Programs Matter|last=Crittenden|first=Camille|date=8 October 2012|work=The Huffington Post|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref>
== History == [[File:International Day of the Girl Child for 2014.jpg|alt=Girls at a 2014 International Day of the Girl Child Event.|thumb|Girls at a 2014 International Day of Girls Event.]] The International Day of Girls initiative began as a project of [[Plan (aid organisation)|Plan International]], a non-governmental organization that operates worldwide.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bwh&AN=201609280700CANADANWCANADAPR.C2019&site=ehost-live|title=Challenge Accepted! Canadian leaders to give up their seats to acknowledge that 'Girls Belong Here' on International Day of the Girl|last=|first=|date=28 September 2016|work=Canada Newswire|subscription=yes|access-date=11 October 2016|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> The idea for an international day of observance and celebration grew out of Plan International's [[Because I Am a Girl (campaign)|Because I Am a Girl]] campaign, which raises awareness of the importance of nurturing girls globally and in developing countries in particular. Plan International representatives in [[Canada]] approached the Canadian federal government to seek to the coalition of supporters [[raised awareness]] of the initiative internationally. Eventually, Plan International urged the [[United Nations]] to become involved.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/katy-ma-/international-day-of-the-girl_b_4080548.html|title=What Is the International Day of the Girl Child?|last=Ma|first=Katy|date=10 October 2013|work=The Huffington Post|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref>
International Day of Girls was formally proposed as a resolution by Canada in the United Nations General Assembly. [[Rona Ambrose]], Canada's Minister for the Status of Women, sponsored the resolution; a delegation of women and girls made presentations in support of the initiative at the 55th [[United Nations Commission on the Status of Women]]. On December 19, 2011, the United Nations General Assembly voted to pass a resolution adopting October 11, 2012 as the inaugural International Day of Girls.<ref name="ambrose1">{{cite news|last=Ambrose, Rona and Rosemary McCarney|title=International Day of the Girl Child: girls' rights are human rights|url=http://blogs.edmontonjournal.com/2011/12/29/international-day-of-the-girl-child-a-canadian-accomplishment/|accessdate=September 26, 2012|newspaper=Edmonton Journal|date=December 29, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719031013/http://blogs.edmontonjournal.com/2011/12/29/international-day-of-the-girl-child-a-canadian-accomplishment/|archivedate=July 19, 2012|df=}}</ref> The resolution states that the Day of Girls recognizes {{blockquote|[the] empowerment of and investment in girls, which are critical for economic growth, the achievement of all [[Millennium Development Goal]]s, including the [[poverty reduction|eradication of poverty]] and [[extreme poverty]], as well as the meaningful participation of girls in decisions that affect them, are key in breaking the cycle of discrimination and violence and in promoting and protecting the full and effective enjoyment of their human rights, and recognizing also that empowering girls requires their active participation in [[decision-making]] processes and the active support and engagement of their parents, legal guardians, families and care providers, as well as boys and men and the wider community [...] <ref>{{cite web|title=Resolution Adopted by the General Assembly: 66/170 International Day of the Girl Child|url=https://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/RES/66/170|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=September 26, 2012}}</ref> |sign=|source=}}
Each year's Day of Girls has a theme; the first was "ending child marriage",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/reproductivehealth/topics/adolescence/idgc/en/ |title=WHO | Ending child marriage |publisher=Who.int |date=2012-10-11 |accessdate=2014-08-21}}</ref> the second, in 2013, was "innovating for girls' education",<ref>[http://www.who.int/maternal_child_adolescent/news_events/events/2013/girl-child-20131011/en/ International Day of the Girl Child], ''WHO''</ref> the third, in 2014, was "Empowering Adolescent Girls: Ending the Cycle of Violence," <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/gender/gender_66021.html|title=Day of the Girl Child - Gender equality - UNICEF|date=17 October 2014|website=UNICEF|accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref> and the fourth, in 2015, was "[[Girl Power|The Power]] of Adolescent Girl: Vision for 2030." The 2016 theme was "Girls' Progress = Goals' Progress: What Counts for Girls,"<ref name=":0" /> the 2017 theme was "EmPOWER Girls: Before, during and after [[crisis|crises]]," and the theme for 2018 was “With Her: A [[Skill]]ed Girl Force.”
By 2013, worldwide, there were around 2,043 events for Day of Girls.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/53110/6-reasons-today-international-day-girl|title=6 Reasons Today is International Day of the Girl|last=Higgins|first=Chris|date=11 October 2013|work=Mental Floss|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref>
==Events worldwide== [[File:Planetarium Hamburg Welt-Mädchentag 2014 FOTO Kinderhilfswerk Plan.jpg|thumb|200px|Buildings (here the [[Planetarium Hamburg]]) are illuminated in the color pink by Plan International to draw attention to the interests of girls worldwide.]] [[File:Pink_Finlandia_2012_1.jpg|thumb|Pink [[Finlandia Hall]] in 2012]] Various events to promote the Day of Girls are planned in several countries. Some are sponsored by the United Nations, such as a concert in Mumbai, India.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bhandary|first=Shreya|title='Because I am a Girl Rock Concert' to celebrate first ever 'International Day of the Girl Child'|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/mumbai/Because-I-am-a-Girl-Rock-Concert-to-celebrate-first-ever-International-Day-of-the-Girl-bbbbnxjsjsjaChild/articleshow/16548066.cms|accessdate=September 26, 2012|newspaper=Times of India|date=September 25, 2012}}</ref> Non-governmental organizations, such as [[Girl Guides Australia]], also support events and activities for International Day of Girls.<ref>{{cite web|title=International Day of the Girl Child|url=http://www.girlguides.org.au/news-events/news-coverage/international-day-of-the-girl-child.html|publisher=Girl Guides Australia|accessdate=September 26, 2012}}</ref> Local organizations have developed their own events, such as Girls and Football South Africa, who, in 2012, distributed T-shirts on International Day of Girls to commemorate the 1956 [[Black Sash]] march by 20,000 women.<ref>{{cite web|title=South Africa: Women, Football and Song|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201209140667.html|publisher=All Africa (orig. in Daily Maverick)|accessdate=September 26, 2012|date=September 14, 2012}}</ref> An all-day event was held on London's [[South Bank]] in 2013, which included theatre and film performances produced by [[Body Gossip]], an organisation that campaigns on body image and mental health issues.<ref name="Guardian blog 11 October 2013">{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/womens-blog/2013/oct/11/body-gossip-models-young-people-image|title= Body Gossip puts spotlight on models and body image |last= Martinson | first= Jane| date= 11 October 2013|publisher= [[The Guardian]]| accessdate= 12 May 2016 }}</ref> For the first Day of Girls, a virtual event was developed by Sage Girl and iTwixie to bring thousands of individuals and organizations together online.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BynVBQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA18&dq=%22international%20day%20of%20the%20girl%22&pg=PA17#v=onepage&q=%22international%20day%20of%20the%20girl%22&f=false|title=Women, Work, and the Web: How the Web Creates Entrepreneurial Opportunities|last=Bent|first=Emily|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2015|isbn=9781442244276|editor-last=Smallwood|editor-first=Carol|location=|pages=17|chapter=Girls' Human Rights and Virtual Empowerment|via=}}</ref>
In 2016, London held a Women of the World (WOW) festival where 250 London school-aged girls were paired with women mentors.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/news/international-day-of-the-girl-406676-406676|title=Women of the World Celebrate the UN International Day of the Girl|last=Proudfoot|first=Jenny|date=11 October 2016|work=Marie Claire|access-date=11 October 2016|via=}}</ref> Also in 2016, President of the [[United States]], [[Barack Obama]], issued a proclamation supporting an end to gender disparity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/10/08/presidential-proclamation-international-day-girl-2016|title=Presidential Proclamation -- International Day of the Girl, 2016|last=|first=|date=7 October 2016|website=The White House|publisher=|access-date=11 October 2016}}</ref>
[[Social media]] uses the [[hashtag]] #dayofthegirl to track events and news about the day.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CXdTDAAAQBAJ&lpg=PT78&dq=%22international%20day%20of%20the%20girl%22&pg=PT78#v=onepage&q=%22international%20day%20of%20the%20girl%22&f=false|title=Jailbreaking the Goddess: A Radical Revisioning of Feminist Spirituality|last=Allen|first=Lasara Firefox|publisher=Llewellyn Publications|year=2016|isbn=9780738748900|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref>

'''Isolation''' (physical, social or emotional) is often used to facilitate [[Abusive power and control|power and control over someone for an abusive purpose]]. This applies in many contexts such as [[workplace bullying]],<ref name="Rayner">Rayner C, Hoel H, [[Cary Cooper|Cooper CL]] Workplace Bullying: What we know, who is to blame and what can we do? (2001)</ref><ref name="Peyton">Peyton PR Dignity at Work: Eliminate Bullying and Create a Positive Working Environment (2003)</ref> [[elder abuse]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canhr.org/factsheets/abuse_fs/html/fs_elderabuse.htm |title=What is Elder Abuse? |publisher=CANHR |date=2016-04-26 |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nap.edu/read/10406/chapter/14 |title=Appendix B: Analysis of Elder Abuse and Neglect Definitions Under State Law | Elder Mistreatment: Abuse, Neglect, and Exploitation in an Aging America | The National Academies Press |doi=10.17226/10406 |publisher=Nap.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref> [[domestic abuse]],<ref name="umich1">{{cite web|url=https://sapac.umich.edu/article/59 |title=Intimate Partner Violence and Common Tactics Used by Abusive Partners | Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center |publisher=Sapac.umich.edu |date=1999-02-22 |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref><ref>Perspectives on Verbal and Psychological Abuse, ed. Dr. Roland Maiuro, PhD, pub. 1989</ref> [[child abuse]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emotionalabuseanswers.org/emoabu/emotional-abuse-behaviors/isolation/ |title=Isolation-Emotional Abuse Answers |publisher=Emotionalabuseanswers.org |date= |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Elliott GC, Cunningham SM, Linder M, Colangelo M, Gross M |title=Child physical abuse and self-perceived social isolation among adolescents |journal=Journal of Interpersonal Violence |volume=20 |issue=12 |pages=1663–84 |year=2005 |pmid=16246923 |doi=10.1177/0886260505281439 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nspcc.org.uk/preventing-abuse/child-abuse-and-neglect/emotional-abuse/ |title=Emotional abuse |publisher=NSPCC |date= |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref> and [[cults]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cultinformation.org.uk/article_caring-for-cult-victims.html |title=Cult Information Centre: Caring for Cult Victims |publisher=Cultinformation.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cultwatch.com/howcultswork.html |title=How Cults Work |publisher=Cultwatch |date= |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref>
Isolation reduces the opportunity of the abused to be rescued or escape from the abuse. It also helps [[Destabilisation|disorientate]] the abused and makes the abused more dependent on the abuser. The degree of power and control over the abused is contingent upon the degree of his or her physical or emotional isolation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rand.org/pubs/papers/P3883.html |title=The Theory and Practice of Blackmail |publisher=RAND |date=1959-03-10 |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Ryan Richard Thoreson |url=https://www.outrightinternational.org/content/blackmail-and-extortion-lgbt-people-sub-saharan-africa |title=Blackmail and Extortion of LGBT People in Sub-Saharan Africa | OutRight |publisher=Outrightinternational.org |date=2010-06-02 |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref>
An important element of psychological control is the isolation of the victim from the outside world.<ref name="WHO 2013 p. 7">[http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/85239/1/9789241564625_eng.pdf ''Global and regional estimates of violence against women: prevalence and health effects of intimate partner violence and non-partner sexual violence.''] World Health Organization. 2013. {{ISBN|978-92-4-156462-5}}. p. 7.</ref> Isolation includes [[Abusive power and control|controlling]] a person's social activity: who they see, who they talk to, where they go and any other method to limit their access to others. It may also include limiting what material is read.<ref name="Duluth model">[http://www.theduluthmodel.org/pdf/PowerandControl.pdf ''Power and Control.''] Duluth Model. Retrieved April 19, 2014.</ref> It can include insisting on knowing where they are and requiring permission for medical care. The abuser exhibits hypersensitive and reactive jealousy.<ref name="WHO 2013 p. 7" />
Isolation can be aided by: * [[Economic abuse#Controlling mechanism|economic abuse]] thus limiting the victim's actions as they may then lack the necessary resources to resist or escape from the abuse<ref name=wdachoices>[http://wdachoices.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/WDAH_flipchart_money_wheel.pdf ''Economic abuse wheel'']</ref> * [[smear campaign|smearing]] or [[Discrediting tactic|discrediting]] the abused amongst his or her community so the abused does not get help or support from others<ref name=Bailey>Bailey-Rug C (2016) It's Not You, It's Them: When People Are More Than Selfish</ref><ref>Joseph Burgo (2016) The Narcissist You Know: Defending Yourself Against Extreme Narcissists in an All-About-Me Age</ref> * [[Divide and rule|divide and conquer]]<ref>Hall J [http://narcissistfamilyfiles.com/2017/03/27/its-you-and-me-baby-narcissist-head-games/ It’s You and Me Baby: Narcissist Head Games] The Narcissist Family Files 27 Mar 2017</ref> * [[gaslighting]] and [[mind control]].<ref name="familysurvivaltrust1">{{cite web|url=http://www.familysurvivaltrust.org/info.php?page=how_cults_operate |title=How Cults Operate |publisher=Familysurvivaltrust.org |date= |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref>
==In cults== {{Main|Cults}} Various isolation techniques may be used by cults:<ref name="familysurvivaltrust1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.criminaljusticedegreesguide.com/features/9-ways-groups-become-cults.html |title=9 Ways Groups Become Cults |publisher=Criminal Justice Degrees Guide |date=2016-09-25 |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/cultmindcontroltechniques/isolation |title=Isolation - Cult Mind Control Techniques |publisher=Sites.google.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-01}}</ref> * separating from family and community * taking control of the handling of the victim's resources and property * [[Undoing (psychology)|undoing]] (mind control) * physical isolation * extortion/dependency tactics * controlling victim's access to necessities.
==In workplace bullying== {{Main|Workplace bullying}} Isolation is a common element of workplace bullying. It includes preventing access to opportunities, physical or social isolation, withholding necessary information, keeping the target out of the loop, ignoring or [[Social exclusion|excluding]].<ref name="Rayner"/><ref name="Peyton"/>
Workplace isolation is a defined category in the workplace power and control wheel.<ref>[http://www.ncdsv.org/images/Duthie_workplace-power-control-wheel_2013.pdf Power & Control in the Workplace] American Institute on Domestic Violence</ref>
==Isolation itself as abuse or punishment== Isolation may itself be considered to be abuse or intended as [[Punishment (psychology)|punishment]] – see [[silent treatment]], [[ostracism]], [[social rejection]], [[shunning]], [[social exclusion]], [[blacklisting]], [[solitary confinement]] and [[sensory deprivation]].
==Non-coercive isolation== Isolation may also be voluntarily sought by an individual or as a response to circumstances without being directly imposed by another – see [[social isolation]], [[emotional isolation]], [[solitude]], [[recluse]] and [[hermit]].

{{Infobox scientist | name = James A. Shapiro | image = | image_size = 110px | alt = James A. Shapiro, phD, with his reading glasses. | caption = James A. Shapiro | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Chicago, Illinois]] | citizenship = | nationality = American | fields = [[Microbiology]], [[Molecular Biology]], [[Genetics]], [[Biochemistry]] | workplaces = [[University of Chicago]]; Postdoctoral Fellow at the [[Institut Pasteur]], [[France]]; [[Harvard Medical School]]; [[Brandeis University]]; Visiting Professor at [[Tel Aviv University]] and the [[University of Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]]; Visiting Fellow at [[Churchill College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]], [[England]] | alma_mater = [[Churchill College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]], [[England]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Natural genetic engineering]], first isolation of a gene, cooperative behavior in bacteria, pattern formation | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = Marshall Scholarship (1964-1966),<ref name="crimson">{{citation|title=Marshalls Announced|journal=[[Harvard Crimson]]|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1964/5/5/marshalls-announced-pfour-harvard-students-and/|date=May 5, 1964}}</ref> Darwin Prize (University of Edinburgh) 1993,<ref name="ucc-obe">{{citation|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/020110/obe.shtml|title=Queen honors Shapiro with OBE|journal=University of Chicago Chronicle|date=January 10, 2002}}</ref> AAAS Fellow 1994,<ref name="AAAS Fellow listing">{{cite web | url=http://www.aaas.org/aboutaaas/fellows/ | title=AAAS Fellow listing}}</ref> Honorary OBE 2001<ref name="ucc-obe"/> | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''James Alan Shapiro'''<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.amazon.com/James-Alan-Shapiro/e/B0050OL5KA | title=Full name}}</ref> (born May 18, 1943) is an [[Americans|American]] biologist, an expert in [[bacterial genetics]] and a professor in the Department of [[Biochemistry]] and [[Molecular Biology]] at the [[University of Chicago]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://bmb.uchospitals.edu/Faculty_and_Research/01_Faculty/01_Faculty_Alphabetically.php?faculty_id=152 | title=Faculty profile, Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, University of Chicago}}</ref>
==Academic biography== Shapiro obtained his Bachelor's degree in English from [[Harvard College]] in 1964.<ref name="crimson"/><ref name="bwsp">{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/13/science/the-biologist-who-saw-a-pattern.html|title=The Biologist Who Saw a Pattern|first=Gina|last=Kolata|authorlink=Gina Kolata|journal=[[New York Times]]|date=October 13, 1992}}</ref> Then, inspired by a [[genetics]] course he had taken as a senior,<ref name="beckwith">{{citation|title=Making genes, making waves: a social activist in science|first=Jonathan R.|last=Beckwith|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=2002|isbn=978-0-674-00928-8}}</ref> he shifted from English to science, earned a doctorate in genetics from [[Corpus Christi College, Cambridge]] in 1968, and did postdoctoral research with [[Jon Beckwith]] at the [[Harvard Medical School]]. He was troubled by the potential [[genetic engineering]] applications of his research.<ref name="beckwith"/><ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/05/science/elusive-genetic-switch-at-last-yields-image-of-its-3-d-structure.html|title=Elusive Genetic Switch At Last Yields Image Of Its 3-D Structure|first=Gina|last=Kolata|authorlink=Gina Kolata|journal=[[New York Times]]|date=March 5, 1996}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Harvard Geneticist Turns to Social Ills|journal=[[Boston Globe]]|first=Richard|last=Knox|date=January 20, 1970}}</ref> He spent two years teaching genetics in [[Havana, Cuba]], before returning to another postdoctorate with Harlyn Halvorson at [[Brandeis University]].<ref name="bwsp"/> Since 1973, he has worked as a professor of microbiology at the University of Chicago, and has also been a visiting professor from time to time, including once as a Darwin Prize Visiting Professor at the [[University of Edinburgh]] in 1994.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://shapiro.bsd.uchicago.edu/cv.shtml | title=Curriculum Vitae, James A. Shapiro | publisher=University of Chicago}}</ref>
==Research== While working with Beckwith at Harvard, Shapiro was part of the first team to isolate a single [[gene]] from an organism.<ref name="bwsp"/><ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1969/11/23/archives/scientists-isolate-a-gene-step-in-heredity-control-scientists.html|title=Scientists Isolate a Gene; Step in Heredity Control|journal=[[New York Times]]|date=November 23, 1969}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1969/12/08/archives/playing-with-biological-fire.html|title=Playing With Biological Fire|journal=[[New York Times]]|date=8 December 1969}}</ref> The gene they isolated was ''[[lac operon|lacZ]]'', which codes for the [[β-galactosidase]] [[enzyme]] used by ''[[E. coli]]'' bacteria to digest the sugars in milk. Their technique involved [[Transduction (genetics)|transduction]] of two complementary copies of the gene into two different [[bacteriophage]]s, then mixing the genetic material from the two phages, and finally using a [[nuclease]] to degrade the single-stranded phage genome, leaving only the double-stranded DNA formed by the two copies.<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ppRmC9-a6JQC&pg=PA42|title=The lac Operon: a short history of a genetic paradigm|first=Benno|last=Müller-Hill|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|year=1996|isbn=978-3-11-014830-5|page=42}}</ref>
In a paper published in the ''[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]]'' in 1979, Shapiro was the first to propose [[replicative transposition]] as a mechanism for gene mobility. In this model, genes such as [[retrotransposon]]s are copied from one [[DNA]] sequence to another via a process in which the two sequences combine to form an intermediate "theta" shape, sometimes called a "Shapiro intermediate".<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8oIaOGHURroC&pg=PA46|title=Lateral DNA transfer: mechanisms and consequences|first=Frederic|last=Bushman|publisher=CSHL Press|year=2002|isbn=978-0-87969-621-4|page=46}}</ref>
Later, Shapiro showed that bacteria cooperate in communities that exhibit complex behavior such as [[hunting]], building protective structures, and spreading spores, and in which individual bacteria may sacrifice themselves for the benefit of the larger community.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/07/05/science/some-thoughts-on-self-sacrifice.html|title=Some Thoughts on Self Sacrifice|first=Malcolm W.|last=Browne|journal=[[New York Times]]|date=July 5, 1988}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/13/science/bacteria-are-found-to-thrive-on-a-rich-social-life.html|title=Bacteria Are Found to Thrive on a Rich Social Life|journal=[[New York Times]]|first=Gina|last=Kolata|authorlink=Gina Kolata|date=October 13, 1992}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Scientist uncovers secret lives of bacteria|journal=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=December 15, 2004|first=Sandra|last=Guy}}</ref> Based on this work, Shapiro believes that cooperative behavior is a fundamental organizing concept for biological activity at all levels of complexity.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/14/science/biologists-tally-generosity-s-rewards.html|title=Biologists Tally Generosity's Rewards|journal=[[New York Times]]|first=Malcolm W.|last=Browne|date=April 14, 1992}}</ref>
Shapiro has also studied [[pattern formation]] in bacteria, an area where he feels that there are new mathematical principles to be discovered that also underlie the growth of [[crystal]]s and the shape of [[cosmology|cosmological structures]].<ref name="bwsp"/> For instance, he found that the gut bacterium ''[[Proteus mirabilis]]'' forms complex terraced rings, an [[emergent property]] of simple rules that the bacterium uses to avoid neighboring cells.<ref>{{citation|title=Making the complex simple|date=January 25, 2001|journal=[[The Economist]]|url=http://www.economist.com/node/484994?Story_ID=484994&CFID=756778&CFTOKEN=91709399}}</ref>
He has proposed the term [[natural genetic engineering]] to account for how novelty is created in the course of biological evolution. It has been criticized by some.<ref>Bezak, Eva (2011). "(Review) Evolution: A View from the 21st Century". Australasian Physical & Engineering Science in Medicine 34 (4): 643–645.</ref><ref>Buratti, Emanuele (2012). "Evolutionary Lessons for 21st Century Molecular Biotechnologists". Molecular Biotechnology 52 (1): 89–90.</ref><ref>Moran, Laurence A (May–June 2011). "(Review) Evolution: A View from the 21st Century". Reports of the National Center for Science Education 32.3 (9): 1–4.</ref><ref>Seoighe, Cathal (2012). "(Review) Evolution: A View from the 21st Century". Trends in Evolutionary Biology 4 (e6): 32–33.</ref>
==Awards and honors== Shapiro was elected to [[Phi Beta Kappa]] in 1963<ref>{{citation|title=16 Elected Phi Beta Kappa At Harvard|journal=[[Boston Globe]]|date=December 8, 1963}}</ref> and was a [[Marshall Scholar]] from 1964 to 1966.<ref name="crimson"/> He won the Darwin Prize Visiting Professorship of the [[University of Edinburgh]] in 1993.<ref name="ucc-obe"/> In 1994, he was elected as a [[fellow]] of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] for "innovative and creative interpretations of bacterial genetics and growth, especially the action of mobile genetic elements and the formation of bacterial colonies."<ref name="AAAS Fellow listing"/><ref>{{citation|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/950119/aaas.shtml|journal=University of Chicago Chronicle|title=Four faculty members elected AAAS Fellows|date=January 19, 1995|volume=14|issue=10}}</ref> And in 2001, he was made an honorary officer of the [[Order of the British Empire]] for his service to the Marshall Scholarship program.<ref name="ucc-obe"/> In 2014 he was chosen to give the 3rd annual "Nobel Prize Laureate - Robert G. Edwards" lecture <ref>[http://www.congressmed.com/cogi World Congress on Controversies in Obstetrics, Gynecology & Infertility (COGI)]</ref>
==Selected publications== Shapiro edited the books ''Mobile Genetic Elements'' (Academic Press, 1983) and, with Martin Dworkin, ''Bacteria as Multicellular Organisms'' (Oxford University Press, 1997). He is the author of ''Evolution: A View from the 21st Century'' (FT Press Science, 2011, {{ISBN|978-0-13-278093-3}}).
